title: Neighborhood Council 10Y
about: The Neighborhood Council (formerly Neighborhood Crime Prevention Council) for beat 10Y exists as a forum to find community solutions to ongoing problems in the neighborhoods of Longfellow (North of 40th St) and Santa Fe. We believe in a holistic approach to crime prevention and work in partnership with the City of Oakland to address ongoing problems in our neighborhoods.   Monthly meetings will be attended by a Community Resource Officer (CRO) – a specifically-designated OPD officer whose position is funded by Measure Z. Any community member (lives, works, or worships) who wishes to regularly attend and participate in meetings is also welcome to join by signing up here. We will often have speakers from the city or community lined up for our meetings.
schedule:
NC 10Y meets on the 4th Wednesday of each month (except December and November). Any community member (lives, works, or worships) who wishes to regularly attend and participate in meetings is also welcome to join by signing up here. Our next meeting is on Wednesday, March 22, 2023 at 6:30 PM..  We are working to find a space to host hybrid meetings for those who would rather attend in person (if you have a space that is amenable to host a hybrid meeting, please email yates@duck.com).

faq.title: Disclaimer: Why reporting a problem is important.
faq.info: For many people, reporting a problem is an obvious first step to solving that problem. However, due to increasing distrust of city services, many people in Oakland are hesitant to involve the city (e.g., the police). Our NC recognizes this reality, but on principle, we take a data-driven approach to understanding what problems our neighborhood is facing. How can we solve a problem if we do not know it exists?\nWhether or not you, personally, believe in the current form of policing in US cities, we urge you to find a constructive way to report the obstacles you are encountering. We will work to create multiple options for you and to build a cohesive accounting of what happens in 10Y. This section is a living document that represents our current understanding of how best to report problems Longfellow and Santa Fe neighbors encounter.

faq.title: How do I report a problem?
faq.info: Depending on the problem (and whether it is a crime and whether you want to involve city services) there are several ways to report. That’s what this faq is for. (Note: this is an evolving document and will likely change as we collect more information).

faq.title: I have a medical emergency
faq.info: From a landline, call 911*. From a cell phone: call the Oakland Fire Department dispatch number 510-444-1616.

faq.title: I am experiencing a criminal emergency.
faq.info: Depending on where the emergency occurs and whether you have access to a landline, there are different options.

faq.title: I have experienced a crime that is no longer an emergency
faq.info: If applicable, and you want to involve the police, report the crime online.

faq.title: I have a problem that is not a crime against a person or my property.
faq.info: use Oak311. The best way to report things that are problems but not person/property crimes (e.g., blocked drains, dead animals, illegal dumping) is to use 311. There are iphone and android apps that facilitate this process.

faq.title: Community Resource Officers
faq.info: Our CRO is Officer Jason Kino (JKino@oaklandca.gov ) and the officer Sylvestre Triana (STriana@oaklandca.gov) is a helpful resource for Area 2 (North Oakland and Uptown)

faq.title: I have a problem and do not want to involve the police
faq.info: There are several community-based organizations that are anti-police. The anti-terror project has a website and a hotline that I could not find in 5 minutes of searching their website.
